subject: Investing
title: Price-to-Earnings Ratio
description: A quick win: understand Price-to-Earnings Ratio.

hook.text: Two companies earn the same profit. One trades at $100, the other at $500. Which is cheaper? You need the P/E ratio.

buildup.text: P/E divides the stock price by earnings per share. A P/E of 20 means you pay $20 for each $1 of profit.

discovery.text: The S&P 500's historical average P/E is about 16. Higher means expensive. Lower means cheap â€” or troubled.

twist.text: Amazon traded at a P/E of 300 for years. Investors paid a fortune for future growth that eventually came.

climax.text: A low P/E can be a bargain or a trap. It might mean the market expects earnings to drop. Context matters.

punchline.text: P/E shows what you pay for profits. Not whether they'll last.

quiz.question: What does a P/E ratio of 20 mean?
options: You pay $20 for every $1 of earnings
